Description: Terracotta phallus. A gigantic phallus, probably once applied to a figure (Harpocrates), as the scar underneath indicates. Probably part of a model group. Perhaps hand-modelled. Micaceous brown Nile-silt with a thick greybrown core and traces of a thin matt red slip.
Curator's comments: Fragment of phallophorous figure, a procession that usually involves a pair of Bes’ and a pair of priests holding Harpocrates’ phallus, who has a naked female tambourine player (wearing a diadem) on his shoulder or head. See Herodotus’ discussion of 5th century processions (History II:48). 5th and 4th century BC parallels of such groups (or fragments of a phallophorous group) have been found at Saqqâra (Martin 1981, Pl.23, 306 probably early 4th century BC), Memphis (Anthes & Bakry 1959, pl.30, no.206; Anthes et. al. 1965, 129 nos 255 and 256; Petrie Museum UC48384-5, UC48391, UC33595-602, UC33605 see also UC47868 and UC48382) and Naukratis (Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl.12.143; Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA581, NA601; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H2805; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.389; Bolton Museum 1886.31.17, 1886.31.16 and 1886.31.15; Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1837; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4694, E.4654 and see E.4720 and possibly the British Museum GR 1973,0501.1, GR 1973,0501.22, GR 1973,0501.32) and unprovenanced (Török 1995, pl.34, no.50; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.83.4, no.455; see also Besques 1992, pl.71 E381; Fischer 1988, nos 1-3). Four smaller handmade ithyphallic figure parallels thought to come from Naukratis (Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge E.119.1914; British Museum GR1973,0501.12; GR1973,0501.18 and GR1973,0501.21;see also Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1975.365). Registered alongside parallels GR1973,0501.1 and GR1973,0501.23 and figures subsequently identified as from Naukratis. Naukratis is the most likely source for this based on the style, fabric, date of the figures and history of the Greece and Rome department’s holdings of Egyptian material (73% are from Naukratis). Anthes, R. & Bakry, H. S. K. 1959. Mit Rahineh 1955, Philadelphia. Anthes, R., Habachi, L., Yoyotte, J. and Jacquet, J. 1965. Mit Rahineh 1956, Philadelphia. Bayer Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Besques, S. 1992. Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre- cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche- Orient. Paris. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber, Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen, Tübinger Studien zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte 14, Tübingen. Martin, G. T. 1981. The sacred animal necropolis at North Saqqâra: the southern dependencies of the main temple complex. Egypt Exploration Society, Excavation Memoirs 50. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
